title_translation.en: Demand for Bengali as State Language in the Parliament
title_translation.es: Demanda del bengal√≠ como idioma estatal en el Parlamento

content_translation.en:
The first session of Pakistan's Parliament was held on February 25, 1948. In the parliamentary proceedings, Congress member Dhirendra Nath Dutta proposed that Bengali should be used alongside Urdu and English. Mr. Dutta's argument was that out of Pakistan's 69 million people, more than 40 million spoke Bengali - meaning Bengali was the language of the majority. Therefore, Bengali should not be seen as merely a provincial language, but should become one of the state languages.

However, Mr. Dutta's amendment proposal was not sustained in Parliament. Even the Bengali members of Parliament could not support it due to objections from their parliamentary party.

In protest of this, students in Dhaka boycotted classes and went on strike. On March 11, 1948, 'Language Day' was observed in East Bengal.

Badruddin Umar wrote that on March 11 in Dhaka, demonstrations were held in front of various government buildings for the Bengali language, and protesters forced two ministers to resign. The military had to be called to remove East Pakistan's Prime Minister Mr. Nazimuddin from the Parliament building.

Police arrested movement leaders including Shamsul Haq, Ali Ahad, and Sheikh Mujibur Rahman - who later became the leader of the 1971 liberation war and founding president of Bangladesh.

In reaction to these leaders' arrests, strikes were held in Dhaka from March 13-15. Two days later, Khaja Nazimuddin met with students from the State Language Action Committee. They agreed that his government would recommend to Pakistan's Parliament to make Bengali one of the state languages.

In this tense environment, just 10 days later, Mr. Jinnah came to Dhaka. And probably referring to this, he mentioned 'creating confusion' in his speech.
content_translation.es:
La primera **session** del parlamento de Pakist√°n se celebr√≥ el 25 de febrero de 1948. En los **proceedings** parlamentarios, el miembro del Congreso Dhirendra Nath Dutta propuso que el bengal√≠ tambi√©n se usara junto con el urdu y el ingl√©s. El **argument** del Sr. Dutta era que de los 69 millones de personas de Pakist√°n, m√°s de 40 millones hablaban bengal√≠, es decir, el bengal√≠ era el idioma de la **majority**. Por lo tanto, el bengal√≠ no deber√≠a verse simplemente como un idioma **provincial**, sino que tambi√©n deber√≠a convertirse en otro idioma estatal.

Sin embargo, esta **amendment** del Sr. Dutta no fue **sustained** en el parlamento. Incluso los miembros bengal√≠es del parlamento no pudieron apoyarla debido a las **objection** del partido parlamentario.

En **protest** por esto, los estudiantes de Dhaka boicotearon las clases e hicieron huelga. El 11 de marzo de 1948 se observ√≥ el 'D√≠a del Idioma' en Bengala Oriental.

Badruddin Umar escribi√≥ que el 11 de marzo en Dhaka se llevaron a cabo **demonstrations** frente a varios edificios gubernamentales por el idioma bengal√≠, y los manifestantes obligaron a dos ministros a **resign**. Tuvieron que llamar al **military** para sacar al primer ministro de Pakist√°n Oriental, Sr. Nazimuddin, del edificio del parlamento.

La polic√≠a **arrest** a los l√≠deres del movimiento, entre ellos Shamsul Haq, Ali Ahad y Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, quien m√°s tarde se convirti√≥ en el **leader** de la guerra de liberaci√≥n de 1971 y presidente fundador de Bangladesh.

En **reaction** a estos arrestos de l√≠deres, se celebraron **strikes** en Dhaka del 13 al 15 de marzo. Dos d√≠as despu√©s, Khaja Nazimuddin tuvo un **meeting** con estudiantes del Comit√© de Acci√≥n del Idioma Estatal. Se acord√≥ que su gobierno **recommend** al parlamento de Pakist√°n hacer del bengal√≠ otro idioma estatal.

En este ambiente **tense**, solo 10 d√≠as despu√©s, el Sr. Jinnah lleg√≥ a Dhaka. Y probablemente refiri√©ndose a esto, mencion√≥ 'crear confusi√≥n' en su discurso.
